header.name: chaos/preprocessor/repetition/delineate_from_to.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that delineates a user-specified target for each number in a specified range.

macro.abstract: The macro repeats its fourth argument for each number in the range specified by its first two arguments with the delineator specified by its third argument between each repetition.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of repeating the target for each number ranging from from to to - 1 (with the delineator specified by sep between each repetition). This is illustrated by the following pseudo-code:
macro(s, from, data) sep() macro(s, from + 1, data) sep() ... macro(s, to - 1, data)

The target is invoked for each number in the half-open range [from, to) with the current (s), the current repetition (n), and, if it exists, the auxiliary data (data or __VA_ARGS__). This target may expand to a in terms of (s). This allows the target to recurse on itself if necessary.

In C99, it is possible to omit the auxiliary data argument altogether. This is different than passing "nothing" as the auxiliary data.
( (0, 10, SEP, MACRO,) // #1 (0, 10, SEP, MACRO) // #2 )
The first line passes "nothing" as the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, 0,) The second line omits the auxiliary data, which causes MACRO to be invoked as (e.g.)... MACRO(s, 0) The fundamental difference is that, in the first line, the auxiliary data is empty (which might have a valid meaning as data), but, in the second line, there is not auxiliary data. Hence, the algorithm is overloaded on a .
Invocations of the target are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with (s), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .
